activity_b.text: What’s the required width of this access platform? It is 666 cm. But this access platform is only 575 cm wide at the moment. This access platform is 91 cm too narrow for safe movement.

What’s the required length of this ceiling frame? It is 37 m. But this ceiling frame is only 34 m long in the current layout. This ceiling frame is 3 m too short for this warehouse.

What’s the required thickness of this protective steel sheet? It is 18 mm. But this protective steel sheet is only 14 mm thick on inspection. This protective steel sheet is 4 mm too thin for reinforcement.
What’s the required capacity of this fuel reservoir? It is 8,500 litres. But this fuel reservoir was only 7,900 litres full this morning. This fuel reservoir was 600 litres too low for operation.
What’s the required pressure in this distribution pipeline? It is 310 bar. But this distribution pipeline is only at 276 bar right now. This distribution pipeline is 34 bar too low for normal flow.

What’s the required voltage for this electrical supply line? It is 415 volts. But this electrical supply line is only at 384 volts under load. This electrical supply line is 31 volts too low for equipment start-up.
What’s the required temperature in this curing chamber? It is 920°C. But this curing chamber is only at 870°C on the display. This curing chamber is 50°C too cold for correct treatment.
What’s the required diameter of this ventilation duct? It is 980 mm. But this ventilation duct is only 900 mm wide in the new section. This ventilation duct is 80 mm too narrow for proper airflow.
What’s the required speed of this conveyor drive unit? It is 1440 rpm. But this conveyor drive unit is only at 1320 rpm when operating. This conveyor drive unit is 120 rpm too slow for production.

activity_b.text: Yesterday was honestly a busy day in the Electronic Technology lab.
The room was hot, and the benches were full.
We tested several power supply circuits near Bench Four.
It wasn’t an easy task for first-year trainees.
The boards were mostly fine, but a few components were faulty.
So, how did you feel doing your first full troubleshooting session?
To be honest, it was harder than I expected.
The circuit diagram was on the board, but it wasn’t very clear at first.
The multimeter was available, but the oscilloscope was in another lab.
That setup wasn’t ideal, and it slowed us down.
Yes, and the PCB was small, so the connections were close together.
The resistors were correct, but one capacitor was damaged.
The solder joints were not clean in some places.
That was a problem, and the circuit wasn’t stable at the beginning.
That’s a common issue.
In electronics, neat work is essential.
If the soldering is poor, the whole circuit becomes unreliable.
The power input was correct, but the output voltage was low.
Was that clear on the multimeter?
Yes, sir.
The reading was low, and it wasn’t changing.
At first, the LED wasn’t on, so we thought the board was dead.
But it wasn’t.
The fault was in the capacitor, not in the IC.
After we replaced the capacitor, the circuit response was better.
The voltage is stable now, and the LED is bright.
There is no overheating, and the waveform looks clean on the oscilloscope.
That was a relief.
Good work.
Today, the lab is much quieter.
There’s no testing session going on now.
We are cleaning benches and checking tools only.
Next week, you’re going to assemble a control circuit and record voltage readings.
Sounds good.
Yesterday was tiring, but the training was very useful.
Next time, we’re going to prepare better, check the diagrams early, and  organise the components properly.
